title: U.K. Regulator Warns About Audit Quality
text:
The U.K. Financial Reporting Council issued a sharp warning about the quality of audits of financial statements in Britain.

The U.K. Financial Reporting Council issued a sharp warning about the quality of audits of financial statements in Britain, a move that comes ahead of the FRC’s integration into a new regulator.

Britain’s watchdog for accounting and audit in its annual report said U.K. audit firms continue to miss the regulator’s 90% target of large company audits requiring no more than limited improvements. This year, 75% of audits reached that goal, the FRC said, slightly up from 73% in the prior year.

“We are not seeing more immediate improvements from the [audit] firms and there is undesirable inconsistency across the market,” Sir Winfried Bischoff, the outgoing chairman of the FRC, said in the report.

The warning comes despite the fact that the FRC stepped up its enforcement efforts during the year ended March 31. The regulator levied £32 million ($39.5 million) in fines on firms, including some of the Big Four companies Deloitte & Touche LLP, Ernst & Young LLP, KPMG LLP and PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP during the year, up from £13.1 million during the prior year. Newsletter Sign-up High-profile corporate collapses and shortfalls in audits of financial statements at U.K. companies have fueled concerns about the work provided by the Big Four accounting firms. Regulators and lawmakers have suggested a flurry of measures to address potential conflicts of interests at large audit companies, but the government has yet to respond to some of the proposals. The FRC appointed a new chief executive in July. Related Coverage SEC Questions Starbucks About Revenue-Recognition Policy

Russel Metals CFO to Retire in 2020

Food Lion Owner Searches for New CFO to Boost Sales, Cut Costs Earlier this year, the U.K. government announced the FRC would become part of a new regulator with extended powers called the Audit, Reporting and Governance Authority. The creation of the body requires new regulation, which hasn’t been passed yet. The regulator in its report singled out two audit firms in particular, KPMG and Grant Thornton U.K. LLP. KPMG “had shown an unacceptable deterioration in quality, and this year we have carried out additional reviews of its audits,” said Stephen Haddrill, the FRC’s outgoing CEO. Grant Thornton has to prepare and implement a detailed action plan to enhance the quality of its audits, the FRC said. KPMG and Grant Thornton didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment.
